Pollyannaish.example: Even in the midst of a lousy sales quarter, Debbie remained Pollyannaish, never losing her shrill voice and wide smile, even when prospective customers hung up on her.

abjure.example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.
abjure.meaning: formally reject or give up (as a belief)

abrogate.example: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.

adjudicate.example: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.
adjudicate.meaning: to serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion

afford.example: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.
afford.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

alacrity.example: The first three weeks at his new job, Mark worked with such alacrity that upper management knew it would be giving him a promotion.
alacrity.meaning: an eager willingness to do something

anachronism.example: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.
anachronism.meaning: something that is inappropriate for the given time period (usually something old).

anathema.example: Hundreds of years ago, Galileo was anathema to the church; today the church is anathema to some on the left side of the political spectrum.
anathema.meaning: a detested person; the source of somebody's hate

anemic.example: After three straight shows, the lead actress gave an anemic performance the fourth night, barely speaking loudly enough for those in the back rows to hear.

anodyne.example: Muzak, which is played in department stores, is intended to be an anodyne, but is often so cheesy and over-the-top that customers become irritated.
anodyne.meaning: something that soothes or relieves pain

anodyne.example: Wilbur enjoyed a spicy Mexican breakfast, but Jill prefered a far more anodyne meal in the mornings.

antic.example: The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears.
antic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

aplomb.example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.
aplomb.meaning: great coolness and composure under strain

apogee.example: The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart's music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.

apostate.example: An apostate of the Republican Party, Sheldon has yet to become affiliated with any party and dubs himself an independent.
apostate.meaning: a person who has abandoned a religious faith or cause

apothegm.example: Winston Churchill is famous for many apothegms, but this might be his most famous: "It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all the others that have been tried."

apotheosis.example: As difficult as it is to imagine, the apotheosis of Mark Zuckerberg's career, many believe, is yet to come.
apotheosis.meaning: exaltation to divine status; the highest point of development

approbatory.example: Although it might not be her best work, Hunter's new novel has received generally approbatory reviews.

appropriate.example: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live.
appropriate.meaning: to give or take something by force
appropriate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

appropriate.example: The committe appropriated the funds to its various members.
appropriate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

appurtenant.example: In hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

arch.example: The baroness was arch, making playful asides to the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious.
arch.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

arrant.example: An arrant fool, Lawrence surprised nobody when he lost all his money in a pyramid scheme that was every bit as transparent as it was corrupt.
arrant.meaning: complete and wholly (usually modifying a noun with negative connotation)

arriviste.example: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.
arriviste.meaning: a person who has recently reached a position of power; a social climber

arrogate.example: Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink, and entertainment.

artifice.example: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.
artifice.meaning: cunning tricks used to deceive others

artless.example: Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.

artlessness.example: I, personally, found the artlessness of her speech charming.

asperity.example: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.

assiduously.example: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

atavism.example: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.
atavism.meaning: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic; throwback

attenuate.example: Her animosity towards Bob attenuated over the years, and she even went so far as to invite him to her party.
attenuate.meaning: to weaken (in terms of intensity); to taper off/become thinner.

autocratic.example: The last true autocratic country is certainly North Korea; nowhere does a leader exercise the absolute control over all aspects of a people the way that Kim Jong-un does.
autocratic.meaning: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule; having absolute sovereignty

autocratic.example: The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.
autocratic.meaning: offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power

baleful.example: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.
baleful.meaning: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments

base.example: She was not so base as to begrudge the beggar the unwanted crumbs from her dinner plate.
base.meaning: the lowest, class were without any moral principles
base.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

bastardization.example: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.
bastardization.meaning: an act that debases or corrupts

beg.example: By assuming that Charlie was headed to college--which he was not--Maggie begged the question when she asked him to which school he was headed in the Fall.
beg.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

bemoan.example: While the CFO carefully explained all the reasons for the cuts in benefits, after the meeting employees bemoaned the cuts as further evidence that management was against them.
bemoan.meaning: express discontent or a stong regret

benighted.example: Far from being a period of utter benightedness, The Medieval Ages produced some great works of theological speculation.
benighted.meaning: fallen into a state of ignorance

bereft.example: After 64 years of marriage, William was bereft after the death of his wife.
bereft.meaning: unhappy in love; suffering from unrequited love

bereft.example: You are not bereft if you haven't played on your Xbox in the past week, his mother said.

besotted.example: Even though her father did not approve, Juliet became besotted with the young Romeo.
Never before have I seen my mom so besotted, and honestly, I hope it's the last time she drinks so much.

bilious.example: Rex was bilious all morning, and his face would only take on a look of contentedness when he'd had his morning cup of coffee.

blinkered.example: In gambling, the addict is easily blinkered by past successes and/or past failures, forgetting that the outcome of any one game is independent of the games that preceded it.
blinkered.meaning: to have a limited outlook or understanding

bowdlerize.example: To recieve an R rating, the entire movie was bowdlerized because it contained so much violence and grotesque subject matter.
bowdlerize.meaning: edit by omitting or modifying parts considered indelicate

bridle.example: New curfew laws have bridled people's tendency to go out at night.
bridle.meaning: the act of restraining power or action or limiting excess

bridle.example: The hostess bridled at the tactless dinner guests who insisted on eating before everybody had gotten their food.

bristle.example: As we discussed the painting, I noticed the artitst's wife bristling at our criticisms, ready to defend her husband's work.
bristle.meaning: react in an offended or angry manner

broadside.example: Political broadsides are usually strongest in the weeks leading up to a national election.

bromide.example: Instead of sharing his umbrella, the cheeky stranger offered Martha the following bromide: "Looks like it's raining."

brook.example: While she was at the chalkboard, the teacher did not brook any form of talking--even a tiny peep resulted in afternoon detention.
brook.meaning: put up with something or somebody unpleasant
brook.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

browbeat.example: During the interrogation, the suspect was browbeaten into signing a false confession.
browbeat.meaning: be bossy towards; discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner

byzantine.example: Getting a driver's license is not simply a matter of taking a test; the regulations and procedures are so byzantine that many have found themselves at the mercy of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

callow.example: Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.

canard.example: The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.

capitulate.example: Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.

cataclysm.example: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.
cataclysm.meaning: an event resulting in great loss and misfortune

catholic.example: Jonah's friends said that Jonah's taste in music was eclectic; Jonah was quick to point out that not only was his taste eclectic but it was also catholic: he enjoyed music from countries as far-flung as Mali and Mongolia.

cede.example: Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing childrens' educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.

celerity.example: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

chagrin.example: Much to the the timid writer's chagrin, the audience chanted his name until he came back on the stage.
She never cared what others said about her appearance but was chagrined by the smallest comment from her mother.
chagrin.meaning: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of

charlatan.example: You may call him a "motivational speaker," but I call him a charlatan--he doesn't have any idea what he's really talking about.
charlatan.meaning: a flamboyant deceiver; one who attracts customers with tricks or jokes

chary.example: Jack was wary of GRE words that looked similar, because they usually had different definitions; not so with chary, a word that he began to use interchangeably with wary.

chauvinism.example: groups/causes Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do.
chauvinism.meaning: fanatical patriotism; belief that one's group/cause is superior to all other
chauvinism.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

chimera.example: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera--a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendancies.
chimera.meaning: something desired or wished for but is only an illusion and impossible to achieve
chimera.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

choleric.example: While a brilliant lecturer, Mr. Dawson came across as choleric and unapproachable--very rarely did students come to his office hours.
choleric.meaning: prone to outbursts of temper; easily angered

churlish.example: The manager was unnecessarily churlish to his subordinates, rarely deigning to say hello, but always quick with a sartorial jab if someone happened to be wearing anything even slightly mismatching.

complaisant.example: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employee and anticipating future requests.
complaisant.meaning: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others

complicit.example: nature. While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.
complicit.meaning: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable

conciliate.example: His opponents believed his gesture to be conciliatory, yet as soon as they put down their weapons, he unsheathed a hidden sword.

concomitant.example: connection with another Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.
concomitant.meaning: describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in

conflagration.example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, do to the heat and lack of rain.
conflagration.meaning: a very intense and uncontrolled fire

conflate.example: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.
conflate.meaning: mix together different elements or concepts

contentious.example: Since old grandpa Harry became very contentious during the summer when only reruns were on T.V., the grandkids learned to hide from him at every opportunity.

corollary.example: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.
corollary.meaning: a practical consequence that follows naturally

cosset.example: The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

coterminous.example: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.
coterminous.meaning: being of equal extent or scope or duration

countermand.example: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.
countermand.meaning: a contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command

cow.example: Do not be cowed by a 3,000-word vocabulary list: turn that list into a deck of flashcards!
cow.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

crestfallen.example: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

crystallize.example: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.
crystallize.meaning: cause to take on a definite and clear shape
crystallize.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

cupidity.example: Some believe people that amassing as much wealth as possible is the meaning to life--yet they often realize that cupidity brings anything but happiness.

curmudgeon.example: Since Uncle Mike was the family curmudgeon, each Thanksgiving he was plied with copious amounts of wine, in the hope that she would become less grouchy.

debonair.example: James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets, and debonair manner.

decry.example: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

defray.example: In order for Sean to attend the prestigious college, his generous uncle helped defray the excessive tuition with a monthly donation.
defray.meaning: to help pay the cost of, either in part of full

deign.example: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.
deign.meaning: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity

demonstrative.example: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.
demonstrative.meaning: given to or marked by the open expression of emotion

denouement.example: outcome of a complex sequence of events At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.
denouement.meaning: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the

derelict.example: The teacher was derelict in her duties because she hadn't graded a single student paper in three weeks.
derelict.meaning: (of a person) not doing one's duties

derelict.example: At one time the waterfront factories were busy and productive, but now they stand derelict and will be torn down.

desiccated.example: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books.
desiccated.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

desideratum.example: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.

despot.example: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.

diatribe.example: Steve's mom launched into a diatribe during the PTA meeting, contending that the school was little more than a daycare in which students stare at the wall and teachers stare at the chalkboard.
diatribe.meaning: a strong verbal attack against a person or institution

diminutive.example: He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: "Bill" instead of "John William."
When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.

disabuse.example: As a child, I was quickly disabused of the notion that Santa Claus was a rotund benefactor of infinite largess--one night I saw my mother diligently wrapping presents and storing them under our Christmas tree.
disabuse.meaning: to persuade somebody that his/her belief is not valid

discursive.example: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.
discursive.meaning: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point

disingenuous.example: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.
disingenuous.meaning: not straightforward; giving a false appearance of frankness

dispensation.example: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.
dispensation.meaning: an exemption from a rule or obligation
dispensation.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

dissemble.example: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.
dissemble.meaning: conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit

dissipate.example: The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico.
Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.

dissolution.example: Many Roman emporers were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.
dissolution.meaning: a living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure
dissolution.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

doleful.example: No event is more doleful than the passing of my mother; she was a shining star in my life, and it brings me great sadness to think that she is now gone.

dolorous.example: Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.

doughty.example: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

dovetail.example: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail each other very well.
dovetail.meaning: fit together tightly, as if by means of a interlocking joint
dovetail.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

duplicity.example: A life of espionage is one of duplicity: an agent must pretend to be a totally different person than who she or he actually is.
duplicity.meaning: deceitfulness, pretending to want one thing but interested in something else

ebullient.example: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

effervescent.example: After the sales result, the manager was in an effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work early that day.
effervescent.meaning: marked by high spirits or excitement
effervescent.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

effrontery.example: The skateboarders acted with effrontery, skating through the church grounds and spray-painting signs warning trespassers.
effrontery.meaning: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to

elegiac.example: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

embryonic.example: The Board of Directors is hoping to launch a new product soon, but planning for the Z7 is in an embryonic stages.
embryonic.meaning: in an early stage of development
embryonic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

empiricism.example: as a way to gain insight and knowledge Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.
empiricism.meaning: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science

enamored.example: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.
enamored.meaning: strongly attracted to, in love with

encumber.example: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

enjoin.example: The government agency enjoined the chemical company to clean up the hazardous dump it had created over the years.
enjoin.meaning: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority

enormity.example: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words--within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.
enormity.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

enthrall.example: She was so enthralled by the movie that she never heard people screaming, "Fire! Fire!" in the neighboring theater.

epigram.example: My favorite epigram from Mark Twain is "A man who carries a cat by the tail learns something he can learn no other way."

epiphany.example: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he prompty quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.
epiphany.meaning: a sudden revelation or moment of insight

eponym.example: named Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.
eponym.meaning: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is

equitable.example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting--at least until the ice cream is gone.
equitable.meaning: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience

equivocate.example: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.
equivocate.meaning: to speak vaguely, usually with the intention to mislead or deceive

ersatz.example: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelley found highly inflated.

estimable.example: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.

ethereal.example: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

evanescent.example: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time--an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.

excoriate.example: Entrusted with the prototype to his company's latest smartphone, Larry, during a late night karaoke bout, let the prototype slip into the hands of a rival company--the next day Larry was excoriated, and then fired.

execrate.example: Though the new sitcom did decently in the ratings, Nelson railed against the show, saying that it was nothing more than an execrable pastiche of tired cliches and canned laughter.

exegesis.example: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis--over the past five centuries there have been as many interpretations as there are pages in the Old Testament.
exegesis.meaning: critical explanation or analysis, especially of a text

exemplar.example: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat, and thoughtful work.

exiguity.example: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

exorbitant.example: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.
exorbitant.meaning: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

expansive.example: After a few sips of cognac, the octogenarian shed his irascible demeanor and became expansive, speaking fondly of the "good old days".
expansive.meaning: communicative, and prone to talking in a sociable manner
expansive.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

expunge.example: When I turned 18, all of the shoplifting and jaywalking charges were expunged from my criminal record.

expurgate.example: The censor expurgated every reference to sex and drugs, converting the rapper's raunchy flow into a series of bleeps.

extrapolate.example: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.
extrapolate.meaning: draw from specific cases for more general cases

facile.example: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.
facile.meaning: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth

factious.example: The controversial bill proved factious, as dissension even within parties resulted
factious.meaning: produced by, or characterized by internal dissension

factitious.example: The defendant's story was largely factitious and did not accord with eyewitness testimonies

feckless.example: Two years after graduation, Charlie still lived with his parents and had no job, becoming more feckless with each passing day.

fecund.example: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

fell.example: For fans of the Harry Potter series, the fell Lord Voldemort, who terrorized poor Harry for seven lengthy installments, has finally been vanquished by the forces of good--unless, that is, JK Rowling decides to come out of retirement.
fell.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

firebrand.example: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.

flag.example: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.
flag.meaning: droop, sink, or settle from or as if from pressure or loss of tautness; become less intense
flag.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

flippant.example: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

flummox.example: Mary's behavoir completely flummoxes me: I never have any idea what her motivations might be.
flummox.meaning: be a mystery or bewildering to

fractious.example: We rarely invite my fractious Uncle over for dinner; he always complains about the food, and usually launches into a tirade on some touchy subject.
fractious.meaning: irritable and is likely to cause disruption

gaffe.example: In a famous gaffe, Vice President Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.
gaffe.meaning: a socially awkward or tactless act

gambit.example: Randy played a gambit, telling his boss that he would leave at the end of the week if he didn't get a raise.
gambit.meaning: a manuveur or risk in a game or conversation, designed to secure an advantage

gerrymander.example: Years ago, savvy politicians had gerrymandered the city center to ensure their re-election.
gerrymander.meaning: to manipulate voting districts in order to favor a particular political party

graft.example: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.
graft.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

grandiloquent.example: The dictator was known for his grandiloquent speeches, puffing his chest out and using big, importantsounding words.

gumption.example: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the U.S. during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

hagiographic.example: Most accounts of Tiger Woods life were hagiographic, until, that is, his affairs made headlines.
hagiographic.meaning: excessively flattering toward someone's life or work

hail.example: Many college superstar athletes are hailed as the next big thing, but then flop at the professional level.
hail.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

halcyon.example: prosperity The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.
halcyon.meaning: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and

hauteur.example: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice begin displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.
hauteur.meaning: overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors

hector.example: The boss's hectoring manner put off many employees, some of whom quit as soon as they found new jobs.

hedge.example: When asked why he had decided to buy millions of shares at the very moment the tech companies stock soared, the CEO hedged, mentioning something vague about gut instinct.
hedge.meaning: to limit or qualify a statement; to avoid making a direct statement
hedge.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

histrionic.example: Though she received a B- on the test, she had such a histrionic outburst that one would have thought that she'd been handed a death sentence.

hoary.example: Most workout gurus are young, fit people, whereas most yoga gurus are hoary men with long white beards.

hobble.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.
hobble.meaning: to hold back the progress of something

hoodwink.example: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

hubris.example: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

illustrious.example: Einstein was possibly the most illustrious scientist in recent history.
illustrious.meaning: widely known and esteemed; having or conferring glory

imbibe.example: Plato imbibed Socrates' teachings to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.
imbibe.meaning: to drink or absorb as if drinking

imbroglio.example: The chef cook-off featured one gourmand who had the unfortunate distinction of mixing the wrong broths, creating an imbroglio that diners would not soon forget.
imbroglio.meaning: a confusing and potentially embarrassing situation

immure.example: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.

impecunious.example: In extremely trying times, even the moderately wealthy, after a few turns of ill-fortune, can become impecunious.

imperious.example: unworthy Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.
imperious.meaning: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as

impervious.example: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.
impervious.meaning: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected

impetuous.example: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.
impetuous.meaning: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation

importune.example: After weeks of importuning the star to meet for a five-minute interview, the journalist finally got what she wanted.

improvident.example: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

impugn.example: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the is idea taken as truth.

impute.example: He imputed his subpar performance on the test to a combination of stress and poor sleep.

inanity.example: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.
inanity.meaning: total lack of meaning or ideas

inchoate.example: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the Middle Ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.
inchoate.meaning: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed

incontrovertible.example: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.
incontrovertible.meaning: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove

indigent.example: In the so-called Third World, many are indigent and only a privileged few have the resources to enjoy material luxuries.
The indigents, huddled under the overpass, tried to start a small bonfire in the hope of staying warm.

ineffable.example: While art critics can occasionally pinpoint a work's greatness, much of why a piece captures our imaginations is completely ineffable.
ineffable.meaning: too sacred to be uttered; defying expression or description

ineluctable.example: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.

inequity.example: After decades of racial inequity, the "separate but equal" doctrine was successfully overturned.
inequity.meaning: injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards

infelicitous.example: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

inimitable.example: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

insouciance.example: Surprisingly, Hank had become a high-powered CEO; his high school friends remembered him as "Hanky Panky", who shrugged off each failed class with insouciance.

insufferable.example: Chester always tried to find some area in which he excelled above others; unsurprisingly, his co-workers found him insufferable and chose to exclude him from daily luncheons out.

internecine.example: The guerilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.
internecine.meaning: (of conflict) within a group or organization

intimation.example: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

inure.example: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.
inure.meaning: to make accustomed to something unpleasant

invective.example: The Internet has unleashed the invectives in many of us; many people post stinging criticism on the comments section underneath newspaper articles or YouTube videos.

invidious.example: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.
invidious.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

inviolable.example: Too many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.
inviolable.meaning: never to be broken, infringed, or dishonored

inviolate.example: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.

irrefutable.example: The existence of life on earth is irrefutable; the existence of intelligent life on earth is still hotly debated.

jaundiced.example: Shelly was jaundiced towards Olivia; though the two had once been best friends, Olivia had become class president, prom queen, and, to make matters worse, the girlfriend of the one boy Shelly liked.
jaundiced.meaning: to be biased against due to envy or prejudice

jejune.example: Although many top chefs have secured culinary foam's popularity in haute cuisine, Waters criticizes it for being jejune and unfilling.
Her boss further cemented his reuptation for being jejune after throwing a fit when the water cooler wasn't refilled.

jingoist.example: In the days leading up to war, a nation typically breaks up into the two opposing camps: doves, who do their best to avoid war, and jingoists, who are only too eager to wave national flags from their vehicles and vehemently denounce those who do not do th
jingoist.meaning: a person who thinks that their country should be at war

juggernaut.example: Napoleon was considered a juggernaut until he decided to invade Russia in winter; after which, his once indomitable army was decimated by cold and famine.
juggernaut.meaning: a force that cannot be stopped

kowtow.example: Paul kowtowed to his boss so often the boss herself became nauseated by his sycophancy.
kowtow.meaning: to bow or act in a subservient manner

lacerate.example: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.
lacerate.meaning: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress
lacerate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

lachrymose.example: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

lampoon.example: Mark Twain understood that lampooning a bad idea with humor was the most effective criticism.

languish.example: Stranded in the wilderness for four days, the hiker languished, eating protein bars and nuts.

lascivious.example: Lolita is a challenging novel for many, not necessarily because of the elevated prose style but because of the depravity of the main character, Humbert Humbert, who, as an old, lascivious man, falls in love with a girl.

limpid.example: Her limpid prose made even the most recondite subjects accessible to all.

litany.example: Mr. Rogers spoke to a Senate committee and did not give a litany of reasons to keep funding the program, but instead, appealed to the basic human decency of all present.
litany.meaning: any long and tedious account of something

loath.example: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.
loath.meaning: unwillingness to do something contrary to your custom (usually followed by 'to')

lugubrious.example: At the funeral, lugubrious songs filled the small church.

machinate.example: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.
machinate.meaning: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together

magisterial.example: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.
magisterial.meaning: offensively self-assured or given to exercising unwarranted power
magisterial.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

malapropism.example: Whenever I looked glum, my mother would offer to share "an amusing antidote" with me--an endearing malapropism of "anecdote" that never failed to cheer me up.
malapropism.meaning: the confusion of a word with another word that sounds similar

malfeasance.example: Not even the mayor's trademark pearly-toothed grin could save him from charges of malfeasance: while in power, he'd been running an illegal gambling rink in the room behind his office.
malfeasance.meaning: misconduct or wrongdoing (especially by a public official)

malingerer.example: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.
malingerer.meaning: someone shirking their duty by pretending to be sick or incapacitated

martinet.example: The job seemed perfect to Rebecca, until she found out that her boss was a total martinet; after each project the boss would come by to scrutinize--and inevitably criticize--every little detail of the work Rebecca had done.

maudlin.example: Just as those who were alive during the 70's are mortified that they once cavorted about in bellbottoms, many who lived during the 80's are now aghast at the maudlin pop songs they used to enjoy--really, just what exactly is a total eclipse of the heart?

maunder.example: Max liked to maunder down by the seaside and pick up whatever sea shells he would stumble upon.
After drinking two expressos each, the animated couple would maunder loudly, annoying the other patrons in the coffee shop.
maunder.meaning: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly

mellifluous.example: Chelsea's grandmother thought Franz Schubert's music to be the most mellifluous ever written; Chelsea demurred, and to her grandmother's chagrin, would blast Rihanna on the home stereo speakers.

mendicant.example: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.
mendicant.meaning: a pauper who lives by begging

meteoric.example: The early spectacular successes propelled the pitcher to meteoric stardom, but a terribly injury tragically cut short his career.
meteoric.meaning: like a meteor in speed or brilliance or transience

mettlesome.example: For its raid on the Bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad, Seal Team Six has become, for many Americans, the embodiment of mettle.

misattribute.example: I made a mistake; I misattributed "Crime and Punishment" to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.
misattribute.meaning: To erroneously attribute; to falsely ascribe; used especially of authorship.

modicum.example: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.
modicum.meaning: a small or moderate or token amount

mordant.example: While Phil frequently made mordant remarks about company policy overall, he always was considerably gentler in discussing any person in particular.
mordant.meaning: biting and caustic in thought, manner, or style

moribund.example: Whether you like it or not, jazz as a genre is moribund at best, possibly already dead.
moribund.meaning: being on the point of death; declining rapidly losing all momentum in progress

mulct.example: The so-called magical diet cure simply ended up mulcting Maria out of hundreds of dollars, but did nothing for her weight.

nadir.example: For many pop music fans, the rap and alternative-rock dominated 90s were the nadir of musical expression.

nettlesome.example: Maria found her coworkers cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

noisome.example: Each August, when the winds moved in a south easterly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.

nonchalant.example: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.

objurgate.example: The manager spent an hour objurgating the employee in the hopes that he would not make these mistakes again.

oblique.example: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.
oblique.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obstreperous.example: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.
obstreperous.meaning: noisily and stubbornly defiant; willfully difficult to control

obtain.example: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.
obtain.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obtuse.example: discernment Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.
obtuse.meaning: slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking in insight or

officious.example: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.
officious.meaning: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner

ossify.example: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.
ossify.meaning: make rigid and set into a conventional pattern
ossify.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

overweening.example: Mark was so convinced of his basketball skills that in his overweening pride he could not fathom that his name was not on the varsity list; he walked up to the basketball coach and told her she had forgotten to add his name.

palatable.example: MIkey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.
palatable.meaning: acceptable to the taste or mind
palatable.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

palaver.example: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.
palaver.meaning: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly
palaver.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

palimpsest.example: iterations can still be seen The downtown was a palimpsest of the city's checkered past: a new Starbucks had opened up next to an abandoned, shuttered building, and a freshly asphalted road was inches away from a pothole large enough to swallow a small dog.
palimpsest.meaning: something that has been changed numerous times but on which traces of former

panacea.example: While the company credit card has made most large purchases easier, it is no panacea: some smaller basic transactions still must be conducted in cash.
panacea.meaning: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; a universal solution

panegyric.example: Dave asked Andrew to do just a simple toast, but Andrew launched into a full panegyric, enumerating a complete list of Dave's achievements and admirable qualities.

paragon.example: Even with the rise of Kobe Bryant, many still believe that Michael Jordon is the paragon for basketball players.
paragon.meaning: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal

paragon.example: Some say that Athens was the paragon of democracy, but these people often forget that slaves and women were still not allowed to vote.
paragon.meaning: an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept

pariah.example: The once eminent scientist, upon being found guilty of faking his data, has become a pariah in the research community.

parvenu.example: higher class The theater was full of parvenus who each thought that they were surrounded by true aristocrats.
parvenu.meaning: a person who has suddenly become wealthy, but not socially accepted as part of a

patent.example: Since the book had been through no fewer than six proof runs, the staff was shocked to see such a patent spelling mistake remaining, right in the middle of the front cover!

pecuniary.example: The defendent was found guilty and had to serve a period of community service as well as pay pecuniary damages to the client.

pellucid.example: The professor had a remarkable ability make even the most difficult concepts seem pellucid.

penurious.example: Truly penurious, Mary had nothing more than a jar full of pennies.
Warren Buffett, famous multi-billionaire, still drives a cheap sedan, not because he is penurious, but because luxury cars are gaudy and impractical.

percipient.example: Even the most percipient editor will make an occasional error when proofreading.

peremptory.example: My sister used to peremptorily tell me to do the dishes, a chore I would either do perfunctorily or avoid doing altogether.

perfunctory.example: The short film examines modern perfunctory cleaning rituals such as washing dishes, doing laundry and tooth-brushing.
perfunctory.meaning: done routinely and with little interest or care

peripatetic.example: Jim always preferred a peripatetic approach to discovering a city: he felt that he could see so many more details while walking.

perspicacious.example: Many modern observers regard Eisenhower as perspicacious, particularly in his accurate prediction of the growth of the military.

phantasmagorical.example: Those suffering from malaria fall into a feverish sleep, their world a whirligig of phantasmagoria; if they recover, they are unsure of what actually took place and what was simply a product of their febrile imaginations.

philistine.example: Jane considered Al completely philistine, because he talked almost exclusive about video games; she was entirely unaware of how well read he really was.
philistine.meaning: smug and ignorant towards artistic and cultural values
philistine.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

phlegmatic.example: Arnold is truly noble, remaining reserved until an issue of significance arises, but Walter is simply phlegmatic: he doesn't have the energy or inclination to care about anything.

picayune.example: English teachers are notorious for being picayune; however, the English language is so nuanced and sophisticated that often such teachers are not being contrary but are only adhering to the rules.

pillory.example: After the candidate confessed, the press of the opposing party took the opportunity to pillory him, printing editorials with the most blatantly exaggerated accusations.
pillory.meaning: ridicule or expose to public scorn
pillory.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pith.example: When Cynthia hears a speaker presenting a complex argument, she is always able to discard the irrelevant details and extract the pith of what the speaker is trying to convey.
pith.meaning: the most essential part of something
pith.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

plucky.example: Some scouts initially doubted Pedroia because of his short stature, but he is a plucky player, surprising everyone with his boundless energy and fierce determination.

ponderous.example: Laden with 20 kilograms of college text books, the freshman moved ponderously across the campus.

pontificate.example: The vice-president would often pontificate about economic theory, as if no one else in the room were qualified to speak on the topic.
pontificate.meaning: talk in a dogmatic and pompous manner
pontificate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

portentous.example: When the captain and more than half the officers were sick on the very first night of the voyage, many of the passengers felt this was portentous, but the rest of the voyage continued without any problems.

precipitate.example: Instead of conducting a thorough investigation after the city hall break-in, the governor acted precipitately, accusing his staff of aiding and abetting the criminals.
The government's mishandling the hurricane's aftermath precipitated a widespread outbreak of looting and other criminal activity.

presentiment.example: On the night that Lincoln would be fatally shot, his wife had a presentiment about going to Ford's Theater, but Lincoln persuaded her that everything would be fine.
presentiment.meaning: a feeling of evil to come

primacy.example: The primacy of Apple Computers is not guaranteed, as seen in the recent lawsuits and weak growth.
primacy.meaning: the state of being first in importance

probity.example: The ideal politician would have the probity to lead, but reality gravely falls short of the ideal of morally upright leaders.

prognostication.example: When the Senator was asked about where the negotiations would lead, he said that any guess he could make would be an unreliable prognostication.
prognostication.meaning: a statement made about the future

prolixity.example: I loved my grandfather dearly, but his prolixity would put me to sleep, regardless of the topic.

promulgate.example: The President wanted to promulgate the success of the treaty negotiations, but he had to wait until Congress formally approved the agreement.

propitiate.example: The two sons, plying their angry father with cheesy neckties for Christmas, were hardly able to propitiate him -- the father already had a drawer full of ones he had never worn before or ever planned to.

prosaic.example: Unlike the talented artists in his workshop, Paul had no such bent for the visual medium, so when it was time for him to make a stained glass painting, he ended up with a prosaic mosaic.

proscribe.example: My doctor proscribes that I not eat donuts with chocolate sauce and hamburger patties for breakfast.

proselytize.example: Lisa loves her Mac but says little about it; by contrast, Jake will proselytize, interrogating anyone with an Android about why she didn't purchase an iPhone.
proselytize.meaning: convert to another religion, philosophy, or perspective

protean.example: Peter Sellers was truly a protean actor--in Doctor Strangelove he played three very different roles: a jingoist general, a sedate President and a deranged scientist.
protean.meaning: readily taking on different roles; versatile

provident.example: In a move that hardly could be described as provident, Bert spend his entire savings on a luxurious cruise, knowing that other bills would come due a couple months later.
provident.meaning: careful in regard to your own interests; providing carefully for the future

puerile.example: Helen enjoyed blowing soap bubbles, but Jim regarded this as puerile, totally unworthy of a woman with a Ph.D.
puerile.meaning: of or characteristic of a child; displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity

puissant.example: Over the years of service, and quite to his surprise, he became a puissant advisor to the community.

punctilious.example: The colonel was so punctilious about enforcing regulations that men fell compelled to polish even the soles of their shoes.
punctilious.meaning: marked by precise accordance with details

pyrrhic.example: George W. Bush's win in the 2000 election was in many ways a pyrrhic victory: the circumstances of his win alienated half of the U.S. population.
pyrrhic.meaning: describing a victory that comes at such a great cost that the victory is not worthwhile

quail.example: Craig always claimed to be a fearless outdoorsman, but when the thunderstorm engulfed the valley, he quailed at the thought of leaving the safety of his cabin.
quail.meaning: draw back, as with fear or pain
quail.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

quisling.example: History looks unfavorably upon quislings; indeed they are accorded about the same fondness as Nero--he who watched his city burn down while playing the violin.

quixotic.example: For every thousand startups with quixotic plans to be the next big name in e-commerce, only a handful ever become profitable.

raconteur.example: Jude is entertaining, but he is no raconteur: beyond the handful of amusing stories he has memorized, he has absolutely no spontaneous story-telling ability.
raconteur.meaning: a person skilled in telling anecdotes

raillery.example: The new recruit was not bothered by the raillery, finding most of it light-hearted and good-natured.

rapprochement.example: Although Ann hoped that her mother and her aunt would have a rapprochement, each one's bitter accusations against the other made any reconciliation unlikely.

rarefied.example: Jack's vulgar jokes were not so successful in the rarefied enviroment of college professors.
rarefied.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

recapitulation.example: Every point of the professors lesson was so clear that the students felt his concluding recapitulation was not necessary.

recrimination.example: The two brothers sat and cried, pointing fingers and making elaborate recriminations of the other's guilt

recrudesce.example: After years of gamblers anonymous, Tony thought he'd broken his compulsive slot machine playing, but it took only one trip to the Atlantic City for a full recrudescence--he lost $5k on the one armed bandit.
recrudesce.meaning: to break out or happen again

redoubtable.example: On television basketball players don't look that tall, but when you stand in front of a seven-foot tall NBA player, he is truly redoubtable.

remonstrate.example: The mothers of the kidnapped victims remonstrated to the rogue government to release their children, claiming that the detention violated human rights.

reprisal.example: The Old Testament doctrine of an eye for an eye is not the kind of retaliation practiced in war; rather, an arm, a leg, and both ears are the reprisal for the smallest scratch.
reprisal.meaning: a retaliatory action against an enemy in wartime

ribald.example: The speaker was famous for his ribald humor, but the high school principal asked him to keep the talk Grated when he spoke to the student body.

row.example: The Prime Minister looked very foolish after his row with the foreign dignitary was caught on video and posted on youtube.
row.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

sagacious.example: Steve Jobs is surely one of the most sagacious CEOs, making Apple the most recognizable and valuable companies in the world.
sagacious.meaning: having good judgement and acute insight

sangfroid.example: The hostage negotiator exhibited a sangfroid that oftentimes was more menacing than the sword at his throat, or the gun at his head.
sangfroid.meaning: calmness or poise in difficult situations

sardonic.example: A stand-up comedian walks a fine line when making jokes about members of the audience; such fun and joking can quickly become sardonic and cutting.
sardonic.meaning: disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking

sartorial.example: Monte was astute at navigating the world of finance; sartorially, however, he was found wanting--he typically would attempt to complement his beige tie with a gray suit and white pants.

saturnine.example: Deprived of sunlight, humans become saturnine; that's why in very northerly territories people are encouraged to sit under an extremely powerful lamp, lest they become morose.

schadenfreude.example: From his warm apartment window, Stanley reveled in schadenfreude as he laughed at the figures below, huddled together in the arctic chill.
schadenfreude.meaning: joy from watching the suffering of others

sedulous.example: An avid numismatist, Harold sedulously amassed a collection of coins from over 100 countries--an endeavor that took over fifteen years, and to five continents.

self-effacing.example: The most admirable teachers and respected leaders are those who are self-effacing, directing attention and praise to their students and workers.
self-effacing.meaning: reluctant to draw attention to yourself

semblance.example: While the banker maintained a semblance of respectability in public, those who knew him well were familiar with his many crimes.
semblance.meaning: an outward or token appearance or form that is deliberately misleading

sententious.example: The old man, casting his nose up in the air at the group of adolescents, intoned sententiously, "Youth is wasted on the young."
sententious.meaning: to be moralizing, usually in a pompous sense

simulacrum.example: The Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center showcases a simulacrum of all the present and approved buildings in the city of Shanghai.
simulacrum.meaning: a representation of a person (especially in the form of sculpture)

simulacrum.example: The early days of computer graphics made real people into a simalacrum that now seems comical.

sinecure.example: The position of Research Director is a sinecure: the job entails almost no responsibilities, nor does the person in that position have to answer to anyone.
sinecure.meaning: an office that involves minimal duties

solecism.example: Mother Anna was always on guard against any solecism from her children and scolded them immediately if any of them talked out of place in public.
solecism.meaning: a socially awkward or tactless act
solecism.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

solicitous.example: Our neighbors are constantly knocking on our door to make sure we are ok, and I don't know how to ask them to stop being so solicitous about our health.
solicitous.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

solicitude.example: I walked to his house in the rain to make sure he had enough to eat while he was sick, but he seemed not to appreciate my solicitude.

spartan.example: After losing everything in a fire, Tim decided to live in spartan conditions, sleeping on the floor and owning as little furniture as a possible.
spartan.meaning: unsparing and uncompromising in discipline or judgment; practicing great selfdenial

splenetic.example: Ever since the car accident, Frank has been unable to walk without a cane, and so he has become splenetic and unpleasant to be around.

squelch.example: After the dictator consolidated his power, he took steps to squelch all criticism, often arresting any journalist who said anything that could be interpreted as negative about his regime.

stalwart.example: Despite all the criticism directed at the President during this scandal, Lisa has remained his stalwart supporter.
stalwart.meaning: dependable; inured to fatigue or hardships

stultify.example: As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain his scholarly edge.
stultify.meaning: cause one, through routine, to lose energy and enthusiasm

subterfuge.example: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.
subterfuge.meaning: something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity

supercilious.example: Nelly felt the Quiz Bowl director acted superciliously towards the underclassmen; really, she fumed, must he act so preternaturally omniscient each time he intones some obscure fact--as though everybody knows that Mt. Aconcagua is the highest peak in Sout
supercilious.meaning: haughty and disdainful; looking down on others

surfeit.example: There was no such thing as a surfeit of shopping for Nancy--she could stay at the outlet stores from opening to closing time.

surreptitious.example: Since his mom was a light sleeper, Timmy had to tiptoe surreptitiously through the entire house, careful to not make the floors creak, until he at last was able to enjoy his plunder: a box of chocolate chip cookies.
surreptitious.meaning: stealty, taking pains not to be caught or detected

sybarite.example: Despite the fact that he'd maxed out fifteen credit cards, Max was still a sybarite at heart: when the police found him, he was at a $1,000 an hour spa in Manhattan, getting a facial treatment.
sybarite.meaning: a person who indulges in luxury

temerity.example: No child has the temerity to go in the rundown house at the end of the street and see if it is haunted.

tempestuous.example: changing or fluctuating Chuck and Kathy had always been stable and agreeable people on their own, but when they got involved, it was a tempestuous relationship.
tempestuous.meaning: as if driven by turbulent or conflicting emotions; highly energetic and wildly

tendentious.example: Because political mudslinging has become a staple of the 24-hour media cycle, most of us, despite protestations to the contrary, are tendentious on many of today's pressing issues.
tendentious.meaning: likely to lean towards a controversial view

transmute.example: One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.
transmute.meaning: change or alter in form, appearance, or nature

trenchant.example: penetration in thought, expression, or intellect Jill presented a rather superficial treatment of sales in Asia, but her trenchant analysis of sales in Europe inspired a number of insights into how to proceed in that market.
trenchant.meaning: characterized by or full of force and vigor; having keenness and forcefulness and

truculence.example: When the boss confronted Aaron about his earlier remarks, Aaron responded with utter truculence, simply throwing a glass of water in the boss' face and walking away.

truculent.example: Standing in line for six hours, she became progressively truculent, yelling at DMV employees and elbowing other people waiting in line.

turgid.example: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years--by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his diehard fans refused to read them.

turpitude.example: During his reign, Caligula indulged in unspeakable sexual practices, so it not surprising that he will forever be remembered for his turpitude.

tyro.example: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time--unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.
tyro.meaning: someone new to a field or activity

umbrage.example: Since he was so in love with her, he took umbrage at her comments, even though she had only meant to gently tease him.
umbrage.meaning: a feeling of anger caused by being offended

unassailable.example: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.

unflappable.example: composure The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.
unflappable.meaning: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and

unforthcoming.example: The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.
unforthcoming.meaning: uncooperative, not willing to give up information

unimpeachable.example: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.
unimpeachable.meaning: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach

unprepossessing.example: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.
unprepossessing.meaning: creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression

unpropitious.example: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.
unpropitious.meaning: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success

unstinting.example: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

untenable.example: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.
untenable.meaning: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified

untoward.example: Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.

untrammeled.example: The whole notion of living untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

unviable.example: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.
unviable.meaning: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).

vaunted.example: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.
vaunted.meaning: highly or widely praised or boasted about

venial.example: His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious--on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.

verisimilitude.example: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

veritable.example: Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

vicissitude.example: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes--massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.
vicissitude.meaning: change in one"s circumstances, usually for the worse

vitriol.example: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racisim that consumed his whole life.
vitriol.meaning: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will

vitriolic.example: While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

vituperate.example: Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.
